statement.p:
Suppose that A = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 7 \end{bmatrix}.
Find an orthogonal diagonalization of A.
Evaluate the quadratic form q_A\left(\twovec11\right).
Find the unit vector \uvec for which q_A(\uvec) is as large as possible. What is the value of q_A(\uvec) in this direction?
Find the unit vector \uvec for which q_A(\uvec) is as small as possible. What is the value of q_A(\uvec) in this direction?

Consider the quadratic form
q\left(\twovec{x_1}{x_2}\right) = 3x_1^2 - 4x_1x_2 + 6x_2^2.
Find a matrix A such that q(\xvec) = \xvec^TA\xvec.
Find the maximum and minimum values of q(\uvec) among all unit vectors \uvec and describe the directions in which they occur.

Suppose that A is a demeaned data matrix:
A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp -2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Find the covariance matrix C.
What is the variance of the data projected onto the line defined by \uvec=\twovec{1/\sqrt{2}}{1/\sqrt{2}}.
What is the total variance?
In which direction is the variance greatest and what is the variance in this direction?

Consider the matrix
A = \begin{bmatrix} 4 \amp -3 \amp -3 \\ -3 \amp 4 \amp -3 \\ -3 \amp -3 \amp 4 \\ \end{bmatrix} .
Find Q and D such that A=QDQ^T.
Find the maximum and minimum values of q(\uvec) = \xvec^TA\xvec among all unit vectors \uvec.
Describe the direction in which the minimum value occurs. What can you say about the direction in which the maximum occurs?

Consider the matrix B = \begin{bmatrix} -2 \amp 1 \\ 4 \amp -2 \\ 2 \amp -1 \\ \end{bmatrix}.
Write the function q\left(\twovec{x_1}{x_2}\right) = \len{B\xvec}^2 in terms of x_1 and x_2.
Find the matrix A such that q(\xvec) = \xvec^TA\xvec.
Explain why A=B^TB.
Find the maximum and minimum values of q(\uvec) among all unit vectors \uvec and describe the directions in which they occur.
What does the minimum value of q(\uvec) tell you about the matrix B?

Consider the quadratic form
q\left(\threevec{x_1}{x_2}{x_3}\right) = 7x_1^2 + 4x_2^2 + 7x_3^2 - 2x_1x_2 -4x_1x_3-2x_2x_3.
What can you say about the definiteness of the matrix A that defines the quadratic form?
Find a matrix Q so that the change of coordinates \yvec = Q^T\xvec transforms the quadratic form into one that has no cross terms. Write the quadratic form in terms of \yvec.
What are the maximum and minimum values for q(\uvec) among all unit vectors \uvec?

Explain why the following statements are true.
Given any matrix B, the matrix B^TB is a symmetric, positive semidefinite matrix.
If both A and B are symmetric, positive definite matrices, explain why A+B is a symmetric, positive definite matrix.
If A is a symmetric, invertible, positive definite matrix, then A^{-1} is also.

Determine whether the following statements are true or false and explain your reasoning.
If A is an indefinite matrix, we can't know whether it is positive definite or not.
If the smallest eigenvalue of A is 3, then A is positive definite.
If C is the covariance matrix associated with a data set, then C is positive semidefinite.
If A is a symmetric 2\times2 matrix and the maximum and minimum values of q_A(\uvec) occur at \twovec10 and \twovec01, then A is diagonal.
If A is negative definite and Q is an orthogonal matrix with B = QAQ^T, then B is positive definite.

Determine the critical points for each of the following functions. At each critical point, determine the Hessian H, describe the definiteness of H, and determine whether the critical point is a local maximum or minimum.
f(x,y) = xy + \frac2x + \frac4y.
f(x,y) = x^4 + y^4 - 4xy.

Consider the function f(x,y,z) = x^4 + y^4 +z^4 - 4xyz.
Show that f has a critical point at (-1,1,-1) and construct the Hessian H at that point.
Find the eigenvalues of H. Is this a definite matrix of some kind?
What does this imply about whether (-1,1,-1) is a local maximum of minimum?
